content: quote: http://www.fayobserver.com/article?id=324032 By George Frey The Associated Press ADVERTISEMENT VILSECK, Germany — A U.S. Army soldier convicted of murder in the 2007 killings of four bound and blindfolded Iraqis was sentenced Thursday to life in prison. Master Sgt. John Hatley, 40, will be reduced in rank to private, forfeit all pay and receive a dishonorable discharge, a jury of eight Army officers and noncommissioned officers decided. He has the possibility of parole after serving 20 years. Hatley and his wife, who sat behind him in the public gallery, both showed no emotion when the sentence was read out. Hatley was found guilty Wednesday of premeditated murder and conspiracy in the execution-style killings of the detainees. He was acquitted of premeditated murder in a separate January 2007 incident in which a wounded Iraqi insurgent was shot and killed. Sad thing to go on, and happen.
reply: By George Frey The Associated Press ADVERTISEMENT VILSECK, Germany — A U.S. Army soldier convicted of murder in the 2007 killings of four bound and blindfolded Iraqis was sentenced Thursday to life in prison. title: A Sad Situation

content: we had a guy in VN who just could not wait to kill someone/something..... pointed his weapon at the kids, mama-san, papa-san, water baffalo's, ducks, you name it.... we tried to tell him to calm down that schit would hit the fan soon enough but he kept up this activity and talking crap.... fortunately for us he disobeyed orders and went off by himself, tripped a boobytrap and screwed himself up pretty good.... he was medvaced out and we didn't have to put up with him anymore... no one missed him.. yepper, some just should never serve.. to bad there is not some sort of screening along these lines to weed out these types. Sadly I fear his "war story" is most interesting. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: I just wish they would make a movie of the initial battle with all the tank action and such going into Iraq and Bagdad on the scale with "The Longest Day", "Battle of the Bulge", or "PAtton" but commiewood don't make that kind of positive stuff anymore - - Oh, I don't know about that! It may be a few decades, but sooner or later they'll cash in on it; it took a while for them to start making movies about the Nam, but eventually the wound's scabbed over in the public mind sufficiently for them to do so and, in a few instances, do a good flick! Of course, in some cases, that just ripped open the wounds of some of the vets! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine

content: Kelly's Heroes, considered to be the best military satire ever made. The guys and characters were everyday during my service time. Don Rickles was the perfect supply sgt.
reply: Kelly's Heroes, considered to be the best military satire ever made. The guys and characters were everyday during my service time. Don Rickles was the perfect supply sgt.
title: A Sad Situation

content: quote: Well ... "The Green Berets" was a complete work of Pentagon propaganda. What's wrong with Pentagon propaganda? Other movies about that era had their own agenda. Born on the Fourth of July was decidely anti-Vietnam but was touted as the true and complete story of the Vietnam experience. But some Vietnam-era vets that I know said it wasn't their experience. Platoon and Casualties of War are more examples of anti-Vietnam movies. Postive movies like We Were Soldiers and The Green Beret seem like a good offset. I don't know what the complete story of the Vietnam experience is. I wasn't there. However, in my dealings with those who were there, it seems that each individual's complete story is as varied as these movies.
quote: Well ... "The Green Berets" was a complete work of Pentagon propaganda.
reply: What's wrong with Pentagon propaganda? Other movies about that era had their own agenda. Born on the Fourth of July was decidely anti-Vietnam but was touted as the true and complete story of the Vietnam experience. But some Vietnam-era vets that I know said it wasn't their experience. Platoon and Casualties of War are more examples of anti-Vietnam movies. Postive movies like We Were Soldiers and The Green Beret seem like a good offset. I don't know what the complete story of the Vietnam experience is. I wasn't there. However, in my dealings with those who were there, it seems that each individual's complete story is as varied as these movies.

content: Saving Ryans privates errr.....Saving Private Ryan!!! Was first class as was Wind Talkers with Nick. Cage. I also loved Tears of The Sun with Bruce Willis it wasn't dedicated to any particular place or time but could easily fit in to many geurilla scenarios around the world. Our present circumstances of asymetric warfare being a case in point. We could wipe out entire civilizations, but find ourselves hard pressed to end it in Iraq and other places, due to "collateral damage" concerns. T

content: quote: Well ... "The Green Berets" was a complete work of Pentagon propaganda. Awful, awful movie - the best to be said about it is that it pumped up the Army. come on now, didn't you love the closing scene, where they walk off on the beach into the sunset? Oh wait, the beaches in Vietnam are on the east-side. There are sunset beaches in Vietnam. Just a minor detail God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans
